sn35.108:4.1: “Mendicants, when what exists, because of grasping what and insisting on what, do people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
sn35.108:5.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn35.108:6.1: “When there’s an eye, because of grasping the eye and insisting on the eye, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’. …
sn35.108:6.3: When there’s a mind, because of grasping the mind and insisting on the mind, people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’.
sn35.108:6.4: What do you think, mendicants? Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
sn35.108:8.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.108:10.1: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
sn35.108:15.1: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
sn35.108:17.1: “But without grasping what’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, would people think ‘I’m better’ or ‘I’m equal’ or ‘I’m worse’?”
sn35.108:19.1: “Seeing this, a learned noble disciple becomes disillusioned with the eye,
sn35.108:19.2: ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn35.108:19.5: When freed, they know ‘it is freed’.
sn35.108:19.6: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’”
